title: Step Ten
subtitle: We continued to take personal inventory and when we were wrong promptly admitted it.

questions.prompt: Why do I need to continue taking personal inventory?
How does continuing to take inventory help me maintain my recovery?
Am I making a daily practice of taking inventory?
How often do I review my day?
Do I write my daily inventory, or do I review it mentally?
What does it mean to take a personal inventory?
What areas of my life do I include in my daily inventory?
Am I looking at my actions, behaviors, and motives?
Am I looking at my relationships?
Am I looking at my thought patterns?
What did I do well today?
Where did I fall short today?
Was I kind, tolerant, and loving today?
Was I dishonest, selfish, or fearful today?
Do I owe anyone an amend for today?
Did I act on any character defects today? Which ones?
Did I practice any spiritual principles today? Which ones?
When I'm feeling upset or disturbed, do I pause and take an inventory?
What patterns am I seeing in these spot-check inventories?
How does a spot-check inventory help me in the moment?
When I've been wrong, do I admit it promptly?
What gets in the way of my admitting when I'm wrong?
How has my willingness to admit my wrongs affected my relationships?
What does 'promptly' mean to me?
Do I wait to admit my wrongs, or do I do it right away?
How does admitting my wrongs promptly benefit me?
How does it benefit others?
Do I stay in touch with what it was like when I was using?
How do I keep the memory of my using fresh?
What am I doing to guard against complacency?
How does continuing to take inventory help me practice honesty?
How does taking inventory help me practice humility?
How does promptly admitting my wrongs help me practice responsibility?
How am I growing spiritually as a result of working this step?
What patterns have I noticed through regular inventory?
How has my life improved since I began practicing daily inventory?
How has working Step Ten prepared me for Steps Eleven and Twelve?
